awd_titl_txt: Regulation of nutrient assimilation in streamlined oligotrophic microorganisms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns cells that compose the "dark matter" of microbial diversity. Many of these organisms are adapted to life in Earth's oceans, where much of carbon flux takes place at very low nutrient concentrations. Some microbes that grow at these low nutrient concentrations' oligotrophs - do not regulate biochemical pathways for nutrient assimilation involving carbon oxidation. In contrast, among the more commonly studied copiotrophs - cells that grow rapidly at high nutrient concentrations - regulation of nutrient assimilation is ubiquitous. An example of a cell that has reduced regulation is Pelagibacter, the most abundant organism in the oceans. At present there exists no explanation for the lack of regulatory systems for nutrient uptake in cells that live in low nutrient ecosystems. In this study, a combination of laboratory experiments, mathematical modeling and genome analysis will be used to examine hypotheses about the costs and benefits of regulating nutrient assimilation. Studying the costs and benefits of different strategies for nutrient assimilation in microbes will aid in the prediction of behavior of nutrient cycles and will lead to a better understanding of aquatic ecosystems. This research may also help scientists understand why so many common microbial cell types have been challenging to grow and study in scientific laboratories. The educational component of this project will involve training a graduate student and a postdoctoral scholar. A workshop on carbon cycling by microorganisms will be presented to teachers and high school students.  

In this project, the investigators will test the hypotheses that nutrient uptake systems may evolve to be unregulated due to (A) cost/benefit of regulation at different frequencies and magnitudes of nutrient pulses, (B) molecular biological constraints that prevent effective operation of a regulatory system at very low nutrient levels (excessive stochastic noise in the regulatory system), or (C) synergy with chemotaxis, which is typically not done by oligotrophs, so they experience nutrient patches at lower concentrations and for shorter times, or some combination of these mechanisms. A model will be developed to explicitly resolve the assimilation systems and their regulation at the gene level, accounting for the dynamics and metabolic costs of protein synthesis and function (Hypothesis A). An agent-based (aka individual-based) modeling approach will be used to explicitly resolve population heterogeneity (Hypothesis B) and individual transport by chemotaxis and diffusion (Hypothesis C). The investigators will also perform nutrient upshift experiments with a number of oligotrophs, copiotrophs and nutrients, to characterize the response times and induction concentration thresholds by measuring transcript abundance and uptake of radiolabeled nutrients. A subset of experiments will additionally include measurements of nutrient and cell concentrations, proteins and metabolites, nutrient uptake and oxidation rates, and growth rates. The data obtained from these experiments model will be used to calibrate and fine tune the model. The synergy between regulation and uptake (Hypothesis C) will also be tested by comparing genomes of oligotrophs and copiotrophs. A postdoctoral scholar and graduate student will be involved in the research and outreach will be performed to high school teachers and students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this NSF grant-supported research we asked why some very abundant plankton cell types have a low percentage of genes devoted to regulation - turning genes on and off. Cells with this property are more abundant in ocean regions that have low rates of photosynthesis, and the percentage of these low productivity ocean regions is increasing as a consequence of ocean warming.  Decades ago we discovered bacteria in the oceans that thrive by oxidizing organic carbon and have unusually small genomes. The first organism of this type that we discovered, SAR11, is the most abundant cell type in the seas. Since then, many other organisms have been discovered that have similar genome properties, which include a high density of genes coding for proteins, a low percentage of guanine and cytosine nucleobases in DNA, a large number of sequence changes that result from mutations, and a relatively low percentage of regulatory genes.  The term "streamlined" is often used to describe microbial cells that have these properties.

            We examined the hypothesis that streamlined cells often do not regulate the expression of genes that code for enzymes which are used to oxidize organic carbon molecules, which are their source of carbon and energy.  Most microbial cells detect organic carbon compounds in the environment and turn genes on and off, depending on whether they are needed, to avoid wasting resources.  Removing regulation and leaving a genes continuously on could result in the cell wasting resources if the carbon compound metabolized by that set of genes is not present in the environment.

            We grew cells from the ocean in the laboratory where we could exactly control their environment.  We compared two bacterial cell types, a SAR11 cell (Pelagibacter) and another cell type that is not streamlined, Alteromonas.  We studied their metabolism of the common amino acid alanine.  As predicted, we found that SAR11 leaves genes for alanine oxidation continuously on, but Alteromonas turns these genes on only when alanine is available in the environment.  The Alteromonas cells needed 2.5 – 4 minutes to turn genes on.

            To understand why streamlined cells might leave their carbon oxidation genes on continuously we built mathematical models in which the levels of nutrients in the environment fluctuated in time and space, and studied how model cells, called "agents", grew in the simulated environments. Often streamlined cells are not motile, so our virtual cells were sometimes motile and sometimes not.  We found that, in simulated ocean environments that fluctuated, the motile cells could find patches with nutrients and remain long enough to turn genes on and benefit, but non-motile cells drifting randomly did not contact patches long enough to benefit from regulation.

            These findings raised the question, how well do the streamlined cells compete?  We found that, while SAR11 cells did not compete well in fluctuating environments, their transport systems for moving organic molecules into the cell were more effective at concentrating nutrients in the low nutrient regions between the high nutrient patches. This trade-off between the benefits of being small and simple vs. larger and more complex helps us understand the distributions of planktonic cells across the oceans and predicts the types of the cells that will compete favorably in expanding ocean regions of high sea surface temperatures and low photosynthetic productivity.

            This project supported two graduate students and two undergraduate researchers, the publication of four scientific papers and one educational paper, and an outreach program that trained high-school teachers from rural Oregon to teach students about planktonic life and the ocean carbon cycle.
